childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 2004-2016

Children born in 2004 grew up in a country that was learning to live with contradictions it couldn't resolve. America was simultaneously at war in two countries and re-electing a wartime president while its citizens were mostly focused on mortgage rates and reality television. The cognitive dissonance was the era's defining feature: everything was fine and nothing was fine, and the adults navigated this by compartmentalizing with impressive efficiency. Dinner, homework, soccer practice—the domestic machinery kept running even as the news reported casualties from a war zone most families couldn't locate on a map without help.

Their earliest years coincided with the brief, strange calm of the mid-2000s—after the initial shock of 9/11 had faded into policy and procedure but before the financial crisis exposed the rot underneath the prosperity. Housing prices were climbing. Parents were refinancing, upgrading, buying SUVs that seemed reasonable at four-dollar gas. The suburban childhood this cohort inhabited felt abundant, if increasingly hurried. Calendars filled with travel teams, enrichment programs, and the particular mania of parents who believed that a child's trajectory could be optimized with the right combination of activities and interventions.

At four, the economy cratered, and the comfortable world of their toddlerhood revealed itself as partially built on debt and speculation. The 2008 crisis entered this cohort's life not as headlines but as changes in routine: a parent home during hours they shouldn't have been, a room in the house that went unpainted, holiday gifts that came with quiet explanations about being grateful for what they had. Kindergarten and first grade unfolded against a backdrop of adult stress that teachers noticed in the children—more anxiety, more behavioral issues, the downstream effects of households under financial pressure seeping into classrooms that were already stretching to meet rising standards.

The Obama years provided the backdrop for most of their elementary school experience, and regardless of household politics, the atmosphere shifted. The wars continued but receded from daily conversation. The economy recovered unevenly—some families bounced back, others found a new, lower equilibrium and stayed there. This cohort's middle childhood had a cautiously optimistic quality, the feeling of a country tentatively exhaling after holding its breath for years. It wasn't exactly relaxed, but it was calmer than what had come before, and dramatically calmer than what was about to arrive.

By the time this cohort reached middle school, the political landscape was fracturing in ways that reached directly into their homes. At twelve, the 2016 election turned family dinners into minefields and school hallways into spaces where opinions could cost friendships. Many children this age encountered, for the first time, the reality that the adults in their life held fundamentally different views about what the country was and should be—and that those differences generated a heat that could burn anyone standing too close. Childhood, as a protected space insulated from the rougher edges of adult conflict, ended earlier for this cohort than anyone had planned.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen Z Generation

Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. Pew Research drew that line and it stuck through repetition. Gen Z is the generation born into the aftermath of 9/11—too young to remember the towers falling, old enough to inherit the surveillance state, the forever wars, and the ambient anxiety they created. By 2030, Gen Z will be the largest generation in the workforce. That's either exciting or concerning, depending on employment status and anxiety levels.

The defining moment for Gen Z was probably the 2016 election, though it depends who one asks and where they grew up. This cohort was twelve when Trump descended that escalator. Old enough to watch the debates, young enough to not vote but feel the consequences ripple through every dinner table conversation. If not 2016, then March 2020—this cohort was fifteen or sixteen when COVID shut everything down. Their sophomore or junior year evaporated into Zoom calls and social isolation. The 'best years of their life' became a Netflix binge with a side of existential concern.

Gen Z didn't adopt social media—they were raised by it, shaped by it, formed in its image. Gen Z inherited every problem and got blamed for none of them. Climate change, economic inequality, housing crisis, healthcare crisis—all of it was broken before Gen Z could vote. Gen Z has responded with dark humor, collective organizing where possible, and a complete rejection of the optimism that Millennials were sold and Gen X cynically refused. Gen Z isn't cynical exactly. They're pragmatic. There's a meaningful difference in how Gen Z approaches broken systems.

Gen Z isn't cynical—they're realistic. Stability was a concept other generations experienced; Gen Z just read about it. Gen Z is the most diverse generation in American history. Gen Z is also the most educated, the most connected, and Gen Z has normalized gender fluidity, mental health discussions, and climate activism in ways that make older generations uncomfortable. That discomfort is genuinely not Gen Z's problem to solve.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 2004 saw Mean Girls come out and accidentally create a religion. 'On Wednesdays we wear pink' became a commandment. The Incredibles proved Pixar could make superhero movies better than most actual superhero movies. Napoleon Dynamite turned awkwardness into an aesthetic that would influence indie culture for a decade. Shrek 2 made more money than the original, which nobody expected.

Musically, 2004 was peak mid-aughts weirdness and variety. Usher's 'Yeah!' dominated everything with Lil Jon's ad-libs. Green Day released American Idiot and became politically relevant again. Kanye West dropped The College Dropout and changed hip-hop forever. Modest Mouse somehow got a mainstream hit with 'Float On.' The music landscape was diverse in ways that algorithms would eventually destroy through optimization.

TV in 2004 launched shows that would become background noise for this cohort's childhood even if they were too young to watch them initially. Lost premiered and spent six years confusing everyone who tried to follow the mythology. Desperate Housewives brought soapy drama back to primetime. Entourage started making terrible men seem aspirational. House proved that being brilliant and rude could be a medical qualification.

Childhood for this cohort was peak Disney Channel original movies and Nickelodeon sitcoms. Their middle school years belonged to Vine's brief glorious chaos, Tumblr's weird corners, and the Hunger Games becoming a cultural phenomenon. By high school, they were on TikTok before adults discovered and colonized it. Their cultural consumption was algorithmic from an early age—they learned to create content before they learned to drive. The parasocial relationship wasn't a new phenomenon for this generation; it was just the default mode of media engagement.

The pop culture this cohort grew up with was endless, on-demand, and personalized to their engagement patterns. They've never had to wait a week between episodes. They've never adjusted their schedule around a broadcast. Binging isn't a choice—it's just how content is consumed. This fundamentally changed their relationship with narrative, patience, and shared cultural experiences.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 2004 saw Gmail launch with one gigabyte of storage that seemed impossibly generous. Google went public and made millionaires of people who'd joined a search engine startup. Facebook was still limited to college students, spreading campus by campus. The internet in 2004 was Web 2.0—user-generated content, social networking, blogs. MySpace existed and mattered. So did Friendster. Neither would survive this cohort's childhood.

World of Warcraft launched in 2004, which meant an entire generation of slightly older kids would spend the next decade in Azeroth instead of developing certain social skills. Mozilla Firefox came out, challenging Internet Explorer's stranglehold on browsing. Flickr launched, pioneering the photo-sharing that Instagram would later perfect and monetize at scale.

This cohort was three when the iPhone launched. They don't remember life before it because they literally couldn't form memories yet. They were six when Instagram started, ten when Snapchat appeared, twelve when TikTok's predecessor Musical.ly arrived. They didn't adopt social media as a choice—they were raised in it. Their first instinct when something interesting happens is to document it, not experience it fully.

This makes them the first true digital native generation without qualification. Millennials remember the before times with dial-up modems and AIM. This generation doesn't. The internet isn't a tool they use—it's the water they swim in. They've never looked something up in a physical encyclopedia. They've never been truly unreachable. They've never experienced the specific boredom that comes from having nothing to do and no screen to fill the void.

This generation's relationship with technology isn't complicated—it's symbiotic. They can't remember their friends' phone numbers because their phone remembers for them. They can't navigate without GPS because why would they memorize routes? They outsource memory, direction, and social connection to devices, which either makes them adaptable or dependent. Probably both.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

This cohort was born three years after the towers fell. They don't remember a world before the War on Terror because there wasn't one during their lifetime. They were {{AGE_AT_IPHONE}} when the iPhone launched, {{AGE_AT_COVID}} when COVID hit. This cohort was born the year the Abu Ghraib torture photos surfaced, revealing what the War on Terror actually looked like when nobody was supposed to be watching. They don't remember it, but it set the tone for American foreign policy during their childhood—justified by fear, executed with cruelty, photographed by the perpetrators.

This cohort was four during the 2008 financial crisis. Their parents' anxiety became their baseline normal. They grew up during the recovery, which for many families meant things never quite returned to what they'd been before. They learned early that stability is conditional and prosperity is not guaranteed to anyone.

This cohort was six when the Deepwater Horizon oil spill happened. They watched footage of an ocean on fire, oil coating birds, a disaster that seemed apocalyptic. It was a decent preview of the environmental disasters that would define their adulthood. Climate change wasn't an abstract future threat—it was birds covered in oil on their TV screen.

This cohort was seven when Osama bin Laden was killed. Their parents probably remember exactly where they were on 9/11. This generation remembers where they were when the mission was announced, probably watching adults celebrate something they didn't fully understand. The war that started before they were born continued after. It would become the longest war in American history, ending only when they were seventeen.

This cohort was twelve when marriage equality became the law. They were twelve when Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson and protests erupted. They were twelve when the ice bucket challenge briefly made everyone care about ALS. Twelve was a significant year for historical events landing.

This cohort was fifteen when COVID-19 shut down the world. Their entire high school experience was disrupted. Proms cancelled, graduations streamed, social development stunted. They spent formative years in isolation, learning to mask (both meanings), and watching adults argue about whether any of it was necessary. They grew up fast, alone, and online.

By the time this cohort could vote at eighteen, they'd already lived through a global pandemic, an attempted insurrection, and the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade. History didn't wait for them to be ready. It never does.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Those born in 2004 are entering the workforce now, or about to. The job market is complex—simultaneously hiring and laying off, demanding experience for entry-level positions, offering remote work while calling everyone back to the office. They've been told they're in a 'hot job market' by people who don't understand that most available jobs don't pay enough to live on in the cities where they're located.

This generation is already being called lazy, entitled, and difficult to manage. This is what every generation says about the next one in an endless cycle. Boomers said it about Gen X. Gen X said it about Millennials. Millennials are saying it about Gen Z. The pattern is predictable. Gen Z isn't lazy—they're correctly identifying that the deal being offered isn't worth taking without negotiation.

Gen Z watched Millennials hustle themselves into burnout and mental health crises. They saw them sacrifice work-life balance for companies that laid them off via Zoom with form letter emails. Gen Z learned that loyalty to employers is a one-way street when it's not reciprocated. Gen Z wants fair pay, reasonable hours, and the ability to exist outside of work. This makes them radical, apparently.

The game isn't rigged against Gen Z specifically—it's just rigged. That's oddly clarifying once they accept it. The gig economy was normalized before Gen Z could work in it. They've never expected a pension because nobody their age has one. They've never expected employer loyalty because they've never seen it demonstrated. They've never expected that a job would take care of them beyond the transaction. This lack of illusion is either depressing or freeing, depending on how one looks at it. The old path—degree, job, promotion, house, retirement—is dead. Gen Z isn't following it; they're building something new on its foundation.

Gen Z is entering a job market being actively rewritten by artificial intelligence. The rules are changing faster than anyone can document them. Remote work was normalized by the pandemic, which benefits Gen Z. They're comfortable with digital collaboration, asynchronous communication, and managing their own time without supervision. The downside is that they never learned how to navigate office politics in person, which still matters even when the office is optional. Someone should probably write a guide for that.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Gen Z has never known dating without apps as infrastructure. Tinder launched when they were nine. Bumble when they were eleven. By the time they were old enough to date, swiping was the standard, as normal as using GPS instead of memorizing directions. Meeting someone in person without digital pre-screening feels almost antiquated, like something people did in movies set before the iPhone.

Gen Z has less sex, starts later, with fewer partners than any generation researchers have measured. This is either a crisis or a correction, depending on who's analyzing it and their assumptions. Gen Z is more cautious, more consent-focused, and more likely to identify somewhere on the asexual spectrum than any previous cohort. The pressure to perform sexuality has decreased. Whether intimacy has also decreased is a more complicated question.

Gen Z communicates primarily through text, DMs, and ephemeral snaps. Voice calls feel intrusive without prior text to schedule them. Video calls feel mandatory after COVID normalized them. Gen Z has developed entire relationships via message, which their grandparents find incomprehensible. Gen Z has also ended relationships via message, which their grandparents find unforgivable.

Gen Z is delaying marriage even more than Millennials did—partly economics, partly intentional choice. Gen Z has watched enough divorces to be cautious about commitment. Gen Z has also seen enough healthy relationships modeled online to know what they want. The bar is simultaneously lower (functional communication) and higher (emotional intelligence, shared values, compatible lifestyles).

Friendship looks different for Gen Z than previous generations. Their closest friends might live in different countries, connected through Discord servers and group chats. Gen Z maintains relationships asynchronously, across time zones, through shared media and memes. Physical proximity is optional. Emotional proximity is everything.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

This cohort was {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}} when the 2008 financial crisis hit. They don't remember it consciously, but their household does—and that anxiety became their inheritance. Their first conscious memories of money involve tension that seeped through the walls. They grew up watching their parents navigate budgets carefully, stress about prices climbing faster than wages. Financial security isn't a destination for Gen Z—it's a moving target that keeps receding as they approach. Economic uncertainty isn't something Gen Z learned in a class—it's something they absorbed through the atmosphere of their childhood home.

Gen Z's relationship with money is defined by having watched everything become more expensive before they could participate. Housing prices tripled during their childhood. Tuition quadrupled. Wages stayed flat. The average home now costs roughly nine times the median income. Their grandparents bought houses at three times their income. The ratio has shifted dramatically against Gen Z.

Gen Z is more likely than Millennials to save aggressively when they have anything to save, invest early through apps, and treat financial literacy as survival training rather than optional enrichment. Gen Z has watched too many TikToks about compound interest to ignore it. Gen Z has also watched too many TikToks about the housing market to believe they'll easily afford a home. The cognitive dissonance is exhausting.

Student loans are a reality Gen Z is facing or will face soon. Average debt for graduates exceeds $30,000, and that's before graduate school. Gen Z is starting their financial life in a hole that previous generations didn't have to climb out of. Homeownership isn't a milestone for Gen Z—it's a math problem that doesn't solve. Every financial milestone—car, apartment, marriage, kids—requires more money than it did for their parents, even adjusted for inflation.

Gen Z has embraced side hustles not as liberation but as necessity. Gen Z has been monetizing hobbies since they were old enough to have them. Content creation isn't a dream job—it's a backup plan for when the regular job falls through. The line between work and life dissolved before Gen Z entered either. Gen Z isn't irrational actors making poor choices—they're rational actors in an irrational system, making the best decisions available.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Gen Z's biggest weakness is the same as its biggest strength: they're chronically online. Gen Z has developed sophisticated media literacy that can spot manipulation, but they've also developed the attention span of a hummingbird. Long-form content feels like work. Nuance gets lost in character limits and time constraints. Gen Z can identify misinformation faster than any generation, but they also get news from TikToks that may or may not be accurate themselves.

Gen Z is so comfortable with digital communication that they've potentially underdeveloped in-person social skills. The pandemic didn't help—it amplified what was already trending. Gen Z missed crucial years of learning to read rooms, navigate awkward silences, and exist without a screen to retreat to. This will matter in job interviews, dates, and any situation where they can't edit their response before sending it.

Gen Z has normalized mental health discussion, which is genuinely good. Gen Z has also potentially over-pathologized normal human experiences. Sadness becomes depression. Nervousness becomes anxiety. Personality quirks become disorders. The vocabulary is helpful for those who genuinely need it and potentially limiting for those who don't. Not every struggle requires a clinical diagnosis.

Gen Z is so aware of systemic problems that individual action can feel pointless. Why recycle when corporations produce most emissions? Why vote when the system is rigged? The macro view is correct, but the micro view matters too. Nihilism dressed as political awareness is still nihilism. Giving up feels rational but isn't actually a strategy for change.

Gen Z is fluent in irony to the point where sincerity feels risky and vulnerable. Everything is a bit, a meme, a reference. Earnestness is cringe. This protects Gen Z from vulnerability but also prevents depth. At some point, Gen Z will need to care about things without a layer of protective irony. It's harder than it sounds.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2024-2034): This cohort is in this decade now, or just entering it. The job market is chaotic and contradictory. Housing is impossible without family wealth or geographic flexibility. They're probably living with roommates or parents longer than they expected or wanted. This is the decade where they're supposed to 'figure things out,' but nobody told them what that actually means in concrete terms. They'll likely change jobs multiple times, not out of flakiness but out of necessity and opportunity. Their twenties will be defined by adaptation, not stability. Get comfortable with uncertainty—it's not going away.

The 30s (2034-2044): By now, they'll have survived their first full decade in the workforce. They'll probably be making more money, though it still won't feel like enough. Housing might become possible, though not in the city they actually want to live in. This is traditionally when people 'settle down,' but Gen Z is redefining what settlement means. Maybe it's homeownership. Maybe it's a van. Maybe it's a co-living arrangement that older generations find baffling. They'll have more clarity about who they are and less patience for pretending otherwise.

The 40s (2044-2054): This will be their peak earning decade, statistically, though statistics don't capture individual reality well. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live, which industries exist, what 'normal' looks like. They'll be managing aging parents, potentially their own kids, and a career that's probably transformed multiple times. The skills they learned in their twenties will be obsolete; their ability to learn new skills will be their most valuable asset. They'll be old enough to be nostalgic for the 2020s, which is a strange thought.

The 50s (2054-2064): Fifty years from their birth. The world will be unrecognizable from today. They'll have lived through climate adaptation (or climate challenges), AI transformation of the economy, and whatever geopolitical shifts happen between now and then. Retirement at 65 probably won't exist the way it did for previous generations. They'll be working in some capacity, whether by choice or necessity. They'll be explaining to younger people what the world was like before—before what, they don't know yet. That's the strange part of forecasting. The biggest changes haven't happened yet.

The 60s and beyond (2064+): If current trends hold, they'll live into their 80s or 90s. Medical technology might extend that further. They'll need financial resources for a longer retirement than any generation before, earned from a more unstable career, in a more expensive world. The math doesn't math, as Gen Z would say. But generations have survived impossible math before. Adaptation is the human superpower. Gen Z has already proven they can adapt to unprecedented circumstances. They'll do it again.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

This cohort is part of a birth group of roughly {{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. The entire Gen Z generation is about 68 million Americans, making it nearly as large as Millennials and poised to become the dominant generation in the workforce by 2030.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), Gen Z is more pragmatic and less optimistic about what institutions can deliver. Millennials believed the system could be fixed with enough effort and voting. Gen Z has never believed the system worked in the first place. Millennials remember the before times with analog childhoods; Gen Z doesn't. Millennials adapted to smartphones in their twenties; Gen Z was raised by them. Millennials have student loan debt and housing trauma; Gen Z watched them struggle and are trying to make different choices, though the math isn't easier.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), Gen Z shares a certain skepticism, but from different sources. Gen X was cynical because they were ignored—the forgotten middle child between Boomers and Millennials. Gen Z is pragmatic because they've been watched and analyzed since birth. Gen X had MTV and mall culture. Gen Z has TikTok and parasocial relationships. Different mediums, similar sense that adults don't understand them. They're right that adults don't understand them.

Boomers controlled 21% of the nation's wealth at Gen Z's age. Gen Z controls about 5%. That's not a typo—it's a transfer. Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the differences are so vast they barely register as the same species occupying the same economy. Boomers bought houses for two years' salary. Gen Z will be lucky to buy a house at ten years' salary in an affordable market. Boomers had pensions, job security, and affordable education. Gen Z has gig work, at-will employment, and crushing student debt. Boomers controlled 21% of the nation's wealth at Gen Z's age. Gen Z controls about 1%. The numbers are not typos.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), Gen Z is practically Luddites. Gen Alpha has had tablets since infancy. Gen Alpha has been documented on social media since birth. Gen Alpha is being raised by AI assistants in ways that haven't fully manifested yet. Gen Z at least remembers a childhood with some analog elements. Gen Alpha won't. Whether that matters, only time will tell.

Gen Z's life expectancy is projected at 77-79 years, slightly lower than Millennials due to rising mental health trends and the health effects of chronic stress, sedentary lifestyle, and climate change impacts. Gen Z is the most connected generation in history—and statistically the loneliest. Both things are true. Both things are related. Gen Z has higher rates of anxiety and depression than any before—though that might be better detection and reduced stigma rather than actual increase. Either way, Gen Z is more medicated, more therapized, and more aware of their mental health than any previous generation. That awareness is both Gen Z's burden and their potential advantage.

year_events: Facebook launched from a Harvard dorm room
Boston Red Sox broke the Curse of the Bambino
Mean Girls became an instant classic
